Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Development of a Process to Extend the Shelf Life of Fruits and Vegetables at Ambient Temperature
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this STTR Phase I project is a sustainable fruit and vegetable processing technology utilizing a new, low temperature technique that can extend the shelf life of pre-cut fruits and vegetables by months without using preservatives, chemicals, freezing, or refrigeration. The technology would enable: all-natural, shelf stable fruit and vegetable products that retain maximum nutritional value, texture, and taste. With significant percentages of the total US national energy budget used for food-related energy, and high fresh produce loss in the developed countries due to insufficient refrigeration, achieving shelf life extension without cold storage or preservatives could drastically reduce energy costs, increase efficiency, and expand access to nutrition globally.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop, validate, and build-upon initial research to evaluate the feasibility and scope of a novel food processing technology. Traditional processing methodologies have fundamental drawbacks. High temperature treatments degrade nutritional quality while altering texture and taste of end-products. Freezing negatively affects the reconstitution properties of fruits and vegetables, and requires high energy consumption throughout the food system to maintain the cold chain. HPP (high pressure processing) has limitations on the enzymes it can inactivate, and chemical alterations from high pressure treatment negatively affects texture and taste. This research proposal will use validation studies to evaluate the feasibility and applicability of the novel processing technique to a variety of fruits and vegetables. Successful experimentation will prove that the application of dense phase gas at low temperatures can overcome the aforementioned drawbacks, achieving enzymatic inactivation, destruction of the spores, improved reconstitution properties, lower energy requirements, and minimal deterioration of taste, texture, and nutritional quality. Such a result would actuate follow-on development work to validate that, at commercial scale, the new process technology improves upon the operational costs of traditional methodologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Farther Farms, Inc. (formerly Natural Cuts, Inc.) has completed the research plan for this Phase I NSF project. The motive of the research was to remedy current and forthcoming food system and environmental challenges by validating and further developing a new, hybrid supercritical fluid food processing technology to produce novel, food safe products that require less energy during processing and throughout the post-processing supply chain. 

The research conducted under this award validated that Farther Farms’ hybrid supercritical technology can effectively produce a shelf-stable, food safe, salable potato product with extended shelf life by inactivating enzymes and meeting the required food safety control points. Such a result indicated the technology warrants large-scale commercialization and could make a significant commercial, social, and environmental impact by reducing the need for freezing and refrigeration while sustainably producing a food safe vegetable product.  Preliminary research indicated that the hybrid process is more efficient and effective than traditional thermal processes. Challenge studies with heat resistant spore forming micro-organisms were shown to achieve a better D-Value curve which can be extrapolated to achieve commercial sterility for pathogens of concern. This would be a boon to food safety by reducing the need for traditional thermal processes to address the pathogenic concerns the industry currently faces.

Further analysis validated the core science and capability of supercritical carbon dioxide and the parent technology to achieve microbiological and enzymatic inactivation for a range of food products beyond potatoes, specifically apple juice, hummus, and guacamole. Through the course of this research, the hybrid system was augmented and reworked to instantly separate a liquid input into its solute and solvent. Based on the successful production and analytical testing results of sucrose, milk, apple and orange juice powders, Farther Farms demonstrated that this drying technique was able to produce shelf-stable end products with a lower temperature and time method than previously possible. At scale, such a technology could be a breakthrough dehydration solution, reducing the current energy consumption, production costs, and thermal exposure of fruit, vegetable, milk, and whey powder processing and sugar production.

 


Last Modified: 05/04/2020
Modified by: Vipul Saran

The motive of the research was to remedy current and forthcoming food system and environmental challenges by validating and further developing a new, hybrid supercritical fluid food processing technology to produce novel, food safe products that require less energy during processing and throughout the post-processing supply chain. The research conducted under this award validated that Farther Farmsâ€™ hybrid supercritical technology can effectively produce a shelf-stable, food safe, salable potato product with extended shelf life by inactivating enzymes and meeting the required food safety control points. Such a result indicated the technology warrants large-scale commercialization and could make a significant commercial, social, and environmental impact by reducing the need for freezing and refrigeration while sustainably producing a food safe vegetable product. Preliminary research indicated that the hybrid process is more efficient and effective than traditional thermal processes. Challenge studies with heat resistant spore forming micro-organisms were shown to achieve a better D-Value curve which can be extrapolated to achieve commercial sterility for pathogens of concern. This would be a boon to food safety by reducing the need for traditional thermal processes to address the pathogenic concerns the industry currently faces. Further analysis validated the core science and capability of supercritical carbon dioxide and the parent technology to achieve microbiological and enzymatic inactivation for a range of food products beyond potatoes, specifically apple juice, hummus, and guacamole. Through the course of this research, the hybrid system was augmented and reworked to instantly separate a liquid input into its solute and solvent. Based on the successful production and analytical testing results of sucrose, milk, apple and orange juice powders, Farther Farms demonstrated that this drying technique was able to produce shelf-stable end products with a lower temperature and time method than previously possible. At scale, such a technology could be a breakthrough dehydration solution, reducing the current energy consumption, production costs, and thermal exposure of fruit, vegetable, milk, and whey powder processing and sugar production.
